subject: Re: [junit] Test Suites Useless?

messageBody:
Bob Sartin wrote:
>>I'd love to hear positive experiences.

On my last project, we used a test finder exclusively, rather than using suites. I found several positives.

1. We never had an instance where we thought a test was being run when it wasn't due to a bad suite.
2. Developers new to the Junit framework only had to know about TestCases, and not Suites.
3. Encouraged better package modularity.
4. There are no suites that have be maintained/Debugged.
5. Every TestCase is automatically part of the whole system test upon creation without have to modify or create a suite.

>>When we created the TestSuite classes initially, we ordered the tests
>>so that the more "primitive" classes are tested first.

Dependencies do present an interesting situation. My compiler knows how to resolve these things, why can't my testing framework? The simple way to do this would be to simply add a way for dependencies to be declared as part of a TestCase. This could also be dictated by package structure, but I think that is putting too much responsibility on packaging. Ideally, the testing framework would be able to discover these things during runtime.

>>So, if we use an automated test finder, it needs to have a way to
>>categorize tests and selectively include/exclude certain categories.
This can easily be done using a naming convention to differentiate classes, or you can subclass TestCase to make cases for different platforms. It depends how you want to discover tests. Do you want to do it based on filename? Or actual class definition? Or some combination?

Regards,
Mike
